title: How to Organize Trophies

steps.headline: Decide which trophies you’d like to keep.
steps.description: If you have a large collection of trophies and some of them don’t mean much to you anymore, you probably don’t need to hang on to them. Go through your trophy collection and decide which ones, if any, you’d like to get rid of. You can take a picture of the ones you’re not keeping as a memento that won’t take up physical space.

steps.headline: Donate old trophies to your local trophy shop, if desired.
steps.description: Contact your local trophy shop to see if they take old trophies—they often do, and this is an easy way to recycle old ones. You can also donate old trophies to Goodwill or the Salvation Army.

steps.headline: Visit your local county's website to learn about recycling options.
steps.description: Most trophies are made of metal or wood, making them recyclable. Go online or call your local county or city's recycling services to find out if recycling your trophies is an option. By typing in your county along with "recycling info," you should find information regarding how and what to recycle.

steps.headline: Choose which trophies you’re going to display.
steps.description: These should be your favorite ones, or the ones that you want everyone to see when they come into your home. Other trophies that you still want to hang on to but don’t need to display right now can be packed away safely.

steps.headline: Place your trophies on a floating shelf for a smaller collection.
steps.description: Depending on the amount of trophies you’d like to display, you can find a floating shelf that will fit them. Floating shelves are easy to install and come in a range of styles, making them a perfect simple display solution. You can purchase floating shelves that have small knobs on the bottom portion, which are great for hanging medals. There's also the option of building floating shelves yourself.

steps.headline: Display trophies in a trophy case or glass cabinet to keep them sealed off.
steps.description: Trophy cases are always an option if you want to display your trophies while keeping them tucked away and out of reach, though super nice ones can get expensive. If you have a glass door cabinet at home, you can also clear off a shelf and place your trophies there. Old china cabinets are also popular display options for trophies.

steps.headline: Store your trophies on a bookcase for an easy fix.
steps.description: It’s likely that you already have a bookcase in your home—clear off a shelf and you have a perfect spot for trophies. Measure the height of your trophies before clearing off the shelf so that you’re sure they’ll fit on the shelf. If you’re trying to organize your kids’ trophies, you can use an entire bookshelf and let each child place their trophies on 1 shelf.

steps.headline: Install shadow boxes for a sophisticated display option.
steps.description: If you just have 1 or 2 trophies, a shadow box is a great way to show them off. Pick out a shadow box in any color or size that you want, and mount it up on the wall. You can even make your own! If you have a larger trophy collection, you can mount lots of different shadow boxes on the wall for a unique look. EXPERT TIP																															Robert Rybarski																Organizational Specialist								Robert Rybarski is an Organizational Specialist and Co-Owner of Conquering Clutter, a business that customizes closets, garages, and plantation shutters to ensure organized homes and lifestyles. Robert has over 23 years of consulting and sales experience in the organization industry. His business is based in Southern California. Robert Rybarski			Organizational Specialist				Our Expert Agrees: Choose the trophies that you treasure the most and display them in a curio cabinet or shadow boxes. That way, you can enjoy those memories and show off your achievements to your friends and family.

steps.headline: Run a shelf along your ceiling to keep trophies out of reach.
steps.description: This works best for larger collections of trophies. Install a floating shelf near the top of your ceiling to keep trophies out of reach, yet also on display. Make sure you measure thoroughly before installing—you don’t want your trophies to be too tall to fit on the shelf.

steps.headline: Take advantage of an alcove in the wall, if possible.
steps.description: If your home has a little alcove that isn’t being used, this could be a great spot for displaying trophies. Install a shelf or place a bookshelf in the alcove to give your trophies their own unique space. You can even hang a picture of the trophy-earning event in the alcove as well. If your alcove has lights that spotlight it, this is a great way to illuminate trophies, medals, and pictures.

steps.headline: Display medals using a curtain rod or nails.
steps.description: If you have a large collection of medals, simply install a curtain rod on the wall and hang all of your medals on the rod. You can also hammer nails into a piece of wood and hang the medals from the nails—this allows you to choose the exact size and spacing that you need. You can purchase medal displays that often come with a spot for pictures at the top, and then either a rod or nails towards the bottom where you hang the medals.

steps.headline: Show off ribbons by hanging them on a thin rope or string.
steps.description: Use strong string, rope, or wire to hold the ribbons. Attach a strand of the string to the wall using nails, creating a horizontal line. Hang the ribbons on the string, and you've created a beautiful ribbon display. You can make the string as long as you need it to hold all of the ribbons. Try organizing your ribbons by color on the string, or hang them randomly for an eclectic look.

steps.headline: Mold bubble wrap around the trophy.
steps.description: Take a piece of bubble wrap and wrap it around your trophy, making sure to get into the crevices and odd angles of the trophy so that it’s fully-protected. Use tape to secure the bubble wrap in place. Using bubble wrap with smaller bubbles will make it easier to mold the trophy with it.

steps.headline: Add an additional outer layer of bubble wrap to the trophy.
steps.description: The outer layer of bubble wrap should reach around the entire trophy, hiding the odd angles of the trophy so that it’s more or less a rectangle or cube. This will give it extra padding to ensure it won’t break.

steps.headline: Label the outside of the wrapped trophy so that you’ll know what it is.
steps.description: Once it’s all wrapped up it will be difficult to see the details of the trophy, so place a piece of masking or painters tape on the bubble wrap. Use a permanent marker to write what the trophy is for. This will prevent you from having to unwrap the trophy to see what it is each time.

steps.headline: Place the bubble-wrapped trophies carefully in a box.
steps.description: You can place a layer of bubble wrap in the bottom and sides of the box for extra padding. Set them in the box carefully so that they don’t break before sealing up the box with tape. Don’t forget to label the outside of the box as well!

text: Sorting the Trophies Decide which trophies you’d like to keep. If you have a large collection of trophies and some of them don’t mean much to you anymore, you probably don’t need to hang on to them. Go through your trophy collection and decide which ones, if any, you’d like to get rid of. You can take a picture of the ones you’re not keeping as a memento that won’t take up physical space. Donate old trophies to your local trophy shop, if desired. Contact your local trophy shop to see if they take old trophies—they often do, and this is an easy way to recycle old ones. You can also donate old trophies to Goodwill or the Salvation Army. Visit your local county's website to learn about recycling options. Most trophies are made of metal or wood, making them recyclable. Go online or call your local county or city's recycling services to find out if recycling your trophies is an option. By typing in your county along with "recycling info," you should find information regarding how and what to recycle. Choose which trophies you’re going to display. These should be your favorite ones, or the ones that you want everyone to see when they come into your home. Other trophies that you still want to hang on to but don’t need to display right now can be packed away safely. Choosing a Display Option Place your trophies on a floating shelf for a smaller collection. Depending on the amount of trophies you’d like to display, you can find a floating shelf that will fit them. Floating shelves are easy to install and come in a range of styles, making them a perfect simple display solution. You can purchase floating shelves that have small knobs on the bottom portion, which are great for hanging medals. There's also the option of building floating shelves yourself. Display trophies in a trophy case or glass cabinet to keep them sealed off. Trophy cases are always an option if you want to display your trophies while keeping them tucked away and out of reach, though super nice ones can get expensive. If you have a glass door cabinet at home, you can also clear off a shelf and place your trophies there. Old china cabinets are also popular display options for trophies. Store your trophies on a bookcase for an easy fix. It’s likely that you already have a bookcase in your home—clear off a shelf and you have a perfect spot for trophies. Measure the height of your trophies before clearing off the shelf so that you’re sure they’ll fit on the shelf. If you’re trying to organize your kids’ trophies, you can use an entire bookshelf and let each child place their trophies on 1 shelf. Install shadow boxes for a sophisticated display option. If you just have 1 or 2 trophies, a shadow box is a great way to show them off. Pick out a shadow box in any color or size that you want, and mount it up on the wall. You can even make your own! If you have a larger trophy collection, you can mount lots of different shadow boxes on the wall for a unique look. Robert has over 23 years of consulting and sales experience in the organization industry. His business is based in Southern California. Robert Rybarski			Organizational Specialist				Our Expert Agrees: Choose the trophies that you treasure the most and display them in a curio cabinet or shadow boxes. That way, you can enjoy those memories and show off your achievements to your friends and family. Run a shelf along your ceiling to keep trophies out of reach. This works best for larger collections of trophies. Install a floating shelf near the top of your ceiling to keep trophies out of reach, yet also on display. Make sure you measure thoroughly before installing—you don’t want your trophies to be too tall to fit on the shelf. Take advantage of an alcove in the wall, if possible. If your home has a little alcove that isn’t being used, this could be a great spot for displaying trophies. Install a shelf or place a bookshelf in the alcove to give your trophies their own unique space. You can even hang a picture of the trophy-earning event in the alcove as well. If your alcove has lights that spotlight it, this is a great way to illuminate trophies, medals, and pictures. Display medals using a curtain rod or nails. If you have a large collection of medals, simply install a curtain rod on the wall and hang all of your medals on the rod. You can also hammer nails into a piece of wood and hang the medals from the nails—this allows you to choose the exact size and spacing that you need. You can purchase medal displays that often come with a spot for pictures at the top, and then either a rod or nails towards the bottom where you hang the medals. Show off ribbons by hanging them on a thin rope or string. Use strong string, rope, or wire to hold the ribbons. Attach a strand of the string to the wall using nails, creating a horizontal line. Hang the ribbons on the string, and you've created a beautiful ribbon display. You can make the string as long as you need it to hold all of the ribbons. Try organizing your ribbons by color on the string, or hang them randomly for an eclectic look. Packing Away the Trophies Mold bubble wrap around the trophy. Take a piece of bubble wrap and wrap it around your trophy, making sure to get into the crevices and odd angles of the trophy so that it’s fully-protected. Use tape to secure the bubble wrap in place. Using bubble wrap with smaller bubbles will make it easier to mold the trophy with it. Add an additional outer layer of bubble wrap to the trophy. The outer layer of bubble wrap should reach around the entire trophy, hiding the odd angles of the trophy so that it’s more or less a rectangle or cube. This will give it extra padding to ensure it won’t break. Label the outside of the wrapped trophy so that you’ll know what it is. Once it’s all wrapped up it will be difficult to see the details of the trophy, so place a piece of masking or painters tape on the bubble wrap. Use a permanent marker to write what the trophy is for. This will prevent you from having to unwrap the trophy to see what it is each time. Place the bubble-wrapped trophies carefully in a box. You can place a layer of bubble wrap in the bottom and sides of the box for extra padding. Set them in the box carefully so that they don’t break before sealing up the box with tape. Don’t forget to label the outside of the box as well!
